On Wednesday 25 May 2005 15:34, Cedric Beust wrote:
> > From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On
> >
> > Not at all. That's what class invariants are for. Each public
> > method is atomic. It is invoked when an object is any legal
> > state and when the method returns it is always careful to
> > leave the object in one of the legal states (barring bad
> > synchronization and complicated multithreaded issues).
>
> That's not what I was saying.  I am sure your code won't crash if the
> method is called without these prerequisites, it's just that it won't be
> doing anything useful (no-op or throwing an exception), so testing it in
> these conditions will be useless:  you need to set up these prerequisites
> before you invoke the method.
>
> > However, a situation where public method A must be
> > invoked before method B is a code smell.
>
> I see code like this every day, and it's not a code smell to me.
>
> It's just what a program is about:  the logical execution of statements in
> a certain order.  Run them in a different order and the program no longer
> does what it's supposed to do.

That's a different issue, though. That the program has different 
effects if method calls are reordered is one thing; that the program 
fails *internally* if they're reordered is another.

For example, consider a Jena RDF Model object (which can be usefully
though of as a set of (S P O) statements, where S P and O are Resources
named by URIs [1]).  You can .add(S P O) and .remove(S' P' O') to
your heart's content, with different S's and P's and O's, and the
Model will eat it all up; you can invoke the methods in any order
you like.

Now, for whatever effect you *want*, there's probably a best ordering,
and lots of broken orderings. Nevertheless, each sequence of add/remove
calls is well-defined [2] - there's no "you must do X to allow Y"
circumstances. 

[1] S and O can also be "blank", ie non-named, Resources, and O can
    can be a literal value, but that doesn't affect this discussion.

[2] Well, a model might be immutable, in which case the well-definition
    is a bit boring - it throws an exception on the first mutation.

-- 
Chris "electric hedgehog" Dollin
"The compiler is free to insert padding because it makes the struct 
look bigger and scares away predators." [Keith Thompson, comp.lang.c]
